awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Social Capital in Employment Referral Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
This project investigates employment referrals for a population currently undergoing displacement and movement, looking at effects of group solidarity, reputation, and competition.  Understanding how individuals integrate into a new community is an important issue with global implications.  Newcomers, like many others, tend to rely on their social networks to find jobs upon arrival to a new destination, which is crucial to their integration. Finding and holding a job can be important for individual self-worth and well-being, beyond helping to contribute financially to the household. The dynamics of the social networks of newcomers and their labor markets can shed more light on how newcomers adapt to new environments. Findings are relevant to decision making concerning employment for newcomers, with implications for non-newcomers as well.

The research questions are addressed through data collected from a survey and through a vignette experiment.  The survey is administered to current and earlier newcomers in two communities that have experienced population movement.  The sampling approach, called Network Sampling with Memory, allows an efficient, representative sample from the target population and generates a map of the social network connecting its members.  The vignette experiment provides evidence of the causal relationship between group solidarity and job referral processes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Claire Le Barbenchon has completed research for her dissertation, “Essays on Migration, Social Networks and Employment”, studying when and under what circumstances migrants are willing to help newcomers find work. During the funding period, she conducted a survey among Latin American immigrants in the Raleigh-Durham area including an embedded experiment, and analyzed the survey data. The results contribute to our substantive understanding of the interplay between ethnic solidarity and social networks.

 Existing work in this area that explores migrant job referral networks focuses mainly on the job searcher side. Claire’s research focuses instead on the referral side of the job search process in order to uncover important insights into how ethnic or migrant solidarity operates at an individual level to produce observed employment outcomes. Despite the wealth of evidence on migrants’ use of networks, little is known about when immigrants choose to help a fellow newcomer with a job referral. One prominent answer points to the role of ethnic solidarity in helping migrants find jobs: individuals tend to help their co-nationals find jobs. However, recent works cast doubt on this assumption, that ethnic solidarity always leads to intra-ethnic support, highlighting the role of competition and reputational risk.

To study this puzzle, Claire developed and deployed vignette experiments among Latin American immigrants to the Raleigh-Durham area.  In the vignettes, she varied the amount of reputational risk a job candidate poses as well as whether the connection between job seeker and referrer is local or transnational. Claire first sought to test whether immigrants are more likely to provide job search support or a referral to individuals who present a lower reputational risk. Results show that, on average,  immigrants are less likely to lend support to newcomers that pose a reputational risk (such as having a spotty employment record). Next, she tested whether co-ethnic or co-home country connection can moderate the effects of reputational risk on likelihood of job search support or a job referral. In this sample, results indicate that being from the same home country can exacerbate the effect of  candidate “risk”, such that Latin American immigrants in this sample are more likely to support a high-risk USA-born candidate than a high-risk candidate from their hometown. In this case, reputational risk appears more salient than home country unity, lending evidence to the idea that immigrants may not always be able to count on co-national support when looking for a job. This has important implications for both research and policy.

Firstly, this work challenges the assumption that immigrant networks are characterized by co-national or co-ethnic solidarity, which should be considered carefully in future studies of immigrant incorporation. Indeed, this work contributes to the literature on immigrant social capital and show that immigrant networks can both support and constrain opportunities for newcomers, depending on the context. Secondly, immigrants who are found to be left out of network-based job support can be targeted by policies that provide alternative job search methods, like placement assistance programs or apprenticeships with local employers.

As part of this study, Claire also deployed a novel network sampling method to collect a portion of the respondents. This resulted in several lessons from the sampling process that can be applied to future projects. Namely, messaging apps can be successfully used to contact participants, data privacy and security is important when collecting network data, and flexibility is required when there are challenges to recruitment.

The study of migrant integration is rapidly becoming an important policy issue facing the international community. As the number of forced migrants continues to grow in contexts of worsening economic and political strife, understanding how immigrants find jobs in a new destination is more important than ever. Studying this through the lens of job-referrals means positioning the immigrant as both a source of and a seeker of help, a framework that is rarely used but is crucial to understanding immigrant integration. Furthermore, by shedding light on the circumstances under which migrants fail to help each other, this work highlights the most vulnerable immigrants: those who do not receive help from their peers. This work is part of Claire's dissertation and she will seek to disseminate the findings through peer-reviewed publications.
